sub_title: Associate Professor at Nyenrode Business University (international investment law)/Director (Dispute Prevention) Asia Pacific FDI Network
summary:
I am a legal expert and practitioner in international investment law, commercial arbitration and Corporate Social Responsibility. 

Currently, I am serving as a Director of Dispute Prevention of the Asia Pacific FDI Network (APFN), which is the most important organization in the region that focuses on researching foreign direct investment and facilitating cooperation among over 100 scholars and 50 institutions. 

Combining academic and practical experience, I am focusing on investment law, commercial arbitration and CSR. The output of my research includes a monograph, an edited volume and numerous peer-reviewed articles and reports. In my academic work, I have contributed to the issue of balancing the rights and obligations of host states and foreign investors in international investment law. My book “The Right of States to Regulate in International Investment Law: The Search for Balance between Public Interest and Fair and Equitable Treatment” (https://law-store.wolterskluwer.com/s/product/right-of-investors-to-receive-fair-equitable-treatment-right-states-reg-publ-int/01t0f00000NY5cN, Wolters Kluwer, 2019) is an in-depth book, specifically helpful for practitioners, focusing on the application of the fair and equitable treatment standard in IIAs . 

I am also a consultant to international organisations. As a legal consultant to the investment team of UNCTAD, I have contributed to the World Investment Report 2019. I have extensive experience working on complex projects within the private sector on issues related to sustainability, environmental law and CSR. I consult UNECE on issues concerning trade and SMEs and I have also advised on Russian law in relation to the legal aspects of foreign direct investment. 

I am also a member of the Chartered Institute of Arbitrators (CIArb), which is the recognised global and trusted thought leader on ADR, operating in multiple jurisdictions.  Additionally, I am sitting as an arbitrator in international commercial disputes.  

As a speaker, I enjoy presenting my research at different international venues, such as the UNCTAD World Investment Forums (2018 and 2019). Over the years, I have initiated and organized numerous international conferences i.e. on COVID-19 and investment law (2020) and the ECT modernisation process (2021), meetings and panel sessions in the Netherlands and abroad.

Open for collaboration. You can reach me by e-mail at j.levashova@nyenrode.nl

projects.title: Book Launch: "Bridging the Gap between International Investment Law and the Environment
projects.description:
The book "Bridging the Gap between Investment Law and the Environment" edited by Yulia Levashova, Tineke Lambooy and Ige Dekker has been launched at the Dutch Ministry Foreign Affairs on 10 November 2015. 

This book addresses the topical question how national and international environmental concerns could be adequately integrated into international investment law. It covers the question whether international investment law restricts state sovereignty in an unacceptable way, in particular the freedom of host states to develop national policies and regulation for the improvement of the environment.
This book first analyzes the interaction between international investment law and the protection of the environment on the basis of concepts such as sustainable development, fair and equitable treatment, and international responsibility. Secondly, several chapters discuss challenges which are encountered in attempts to integrate environmental concerns in investment policies in specific sectors and regions (e.g. climate change, water pollution, renewable and nuclear energy, and the European Union region). And, thirdly, specific case studies illustrate the legal and policy tensions between investment law and environmental protection, namely Vattenfall’s disputes with Germany, legal clashes between Chevron and Ecuador, and multinational mining companies’ conflicts in Indonesia.
The contributions are written by international experts in this fiel and are of interest to valuable for policy makers and practitioners, who can use the insights provided as a guide in their work.

projects.title: Bridging the Gap between International Investment Law and the Environment
projects.description:
The goal of the project ( http://www.utrechtjournal.org/article/view/ujiel.cj) is to develop the academic and policy debate in the field of international investment law and the environment. In the framework of this project the international conference was organised on 4 and 5 November 2013. The conference (http://iilconference.com/index.html) took place at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the Hague, the Netherlands. This conference was organised by the Research Center for Water, Oceans and Sustainability Law of Utrecht University Law School and the Center for 
Sustainability of Nyenrode Business University. The conference was supported by The Dutch 
Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment, the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the 
law firm Pels Rijcken & Droogleever Fortuijn. 

In the framework of this project the book entitled 'Bridging the Gap between International Investment Law and the Environment' will be published in the book series 'Legal Perspectives on Global Challenges' by Eleven Legal Publishing. The book will be based on the  papers presented during the conference. The editors of the book are Yulia Levashova, Tineke Lambooy and Ige Dekker. 
The book that will contain the contributions of the leading experts in the field of international investment law and the environmental law will be focused on four subjects: (1) general principles of 
international investment law and the environment, (2) various legal regimes, (3) specific legal 
regimes, and (4) case studies. The publication date is expected in the Summer/Fall 2014.

projects.title: European Timber Regulation
projects.description:
Are you aware that when you buy furniture at the store it is most likely to be produced from wood which is illegally cut? 
 
It was estimated  that between 20-40% of global industrial wood that enters the European market comes from illegal sources.  What are the consequences of that?
 
Firstly, illegal logging  is a driving force behind deforestation, which accounts for about 20% of global greenhouse emissions. The reduction of  deforestation, by eliminating  illegal logging, is the easiest ways to reduce emissions.
 
Secondly, illegal logging promotes corruption and destabilize the rule of law and good governance, specifically in developing producer–countries. 
 
Thirdly, according to the World Bank,  illegal logging  results in governments’ revenue losses estimated as over 15 billion dollars every year in developing countries alone.  Fourthly,  businesses that operate “sustainable  timber policies”, e.g. Ikea, are  often loosing parties because of an absence of a level of  playing field in the timber sector.  
 
So, what are the barriers that prevent the use and import of legal timber? What are the necessary measures to eliminate  the illegal logging?
 
This project analyses  the state of affairs concerning the use and import of illegal timber in the Netherlands and in the EU. The central role is devoted to legislation that aims to put an end to illegal logging. The new EU regulation  plays a central role. The focus of the analysis of the Regulation lies on the implementation procedure in the Netherlands. The organization of working conferences/workshops is planned in the framework of this project.

projects.title: Working conference "Boosting investments in Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services"
projects.description:
The conference aimed to stimulate investments that support biodiversity conservation and explore the interest of participants in collaborative action for further development of this field.

The specific objectives of the conference were to inform participants on the current status of the market, provide details of a number of interesting Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (BES) investment funds, analyse developing initiatives, address relevant governmental policies, and identify opportunities and barriers in the BES market.
